published_attributes.title: Course overview
published_attributes.serialized_body:
In this course we'll share some standards that we would like any Netguru Python developer to stick to. If you are up to date with Python, most probably you know most of them, but still it's worth to read it and refresh your knowledge.

Get ready!

published_attributes.title: General rules
published_attributes.serialized_body:
• Use class based views in Django, especially generic views when it’s possible. The same applies to forms and API endpoints.
  • Create templates that extends some basic template - keep it DRY as much as possible.
  • Comply with the rules of PEP8.
  • Use generators.
  • Remember to parametrize settings.py file by usage of environment variables.
  • Remember to add all dependencies you are using in requirements.txt file.
  • Do not delete migrations that were already applied on existing instances on staging or production.
  • Do not add any data to the repository that could compromise security, for example login credentials or API KEYS
  • Make sure README.md and .gitignore are up to date and no unnecessary files are in repository.
  • You can generate .gitignore file here: https://www.gitignore.io/
  • Remember to write unit tests and documentation for code. One of the good test framework is called PyTest. It's possible to use it with raw Python code as well as with Django framework (instructions can be found here).
  • Remember to add logging of important operations or connections with external API, especially in case something during execution went wrong.

published_attributes.title: The list of bugs which cannot get into tester’s hands
published_attributes.serialized_body:
• backend field validation
  • uploading files with special characters (f.e. an image or a PDF file)
  • incorrect error codes
  • different date formats
  • problem with user authorisation (user A has an access to resources of user B)
  • incorrect links after changing environment (f.e. we get an activation link: project.dev/activate/{code} on a production version of application)
  • incorrect types returned for keywords in JSON

published_attributes.title: Development checks
published_attributes.serialized_body:
These checks should be done during code review. Additional checks should also be done before production release.

  • Critical checks:
    • backend validation for critical data,
    • endpoints correct authorization and authentication settings,
    • up to date requirements.txt file,
    • consistent and working migrations,
    • passing CI linters checks,
    • passing unit tests.

  • Non critical checks (can be passed but has to be justified):
    • usage of hardcoded values, everything should be created with portability in mind,
    • missing optimization on difficult database queries,
    • time consuming operations in request handling (e.g. sending emails synchronously during request processing),
    • not following all coding standards,
    • using wrong HTTP methods for different actions in REST API (e.g. GET for writing data)
    • wrong response status codes (e.g. status 200 OK for returning message with error cause,
    • missing documentation of how to deploy application,
    • missing ability to upload files with special characters in file name,
    • more than one date format standard used in project

published_attributes.title: Deployment checks
published_attributes.serialized_body:
All critical deployment checks should be passed before publishing application.

  • Critical:
    • all development checks should be passed before deployment,
    • using DEBUG=True setting on production environment,
    • incorrect file chmods and chowns.
  • Not always critical:
    • no automated log rotation,
    • HTTPS not set,
    • additional checks for Django can be done by running:./manage.py check --deploy

published_attributes.title: Linters
published_attributes.serialized_body:
PyCharm IDE analyzes code on-the-fly and informs user about found errors. It also offers inspection profiles that allow pointing out which type of errors should IDE look for. More about PyCharm built in linter functionalities can be found here.

It's also a good idea to use Python dedicated linters, for example Flake8 or pylint:

  • Flake8 mainly performs PEP8 checks. It can be used with CI's, especially with Hound as it requires very little configuration. Description on how to run Flake8 can be found here.
  • pylint offers some more sophisticated and its output is very rich in details. It also can be integrated with PyCharm (instructions here) as well as with CI's. Description on how to run pylint can be found here.

Other code quality tools

  • CodeBeat - can be easily integrated with Github, Bitbucket and GitLab. CodeBeat performs several code checks and outputs general project quality, separate projects files ratings as well as suggestions of what can be done to rise project quality.
  • Hound - performs automatic code reviews during pull requests. It's possible to check code for a lot of different languages, including JavaScript, Ruby, Python, Go. Especially for Python, Hound offers Flake8 linter. Instruction on how to setup Hound to work with Flake8 can be found here.

published_attributes.title: Static typing
published_attributes.serialized_body: Python offers static typing mechanism for explicitly stating type of variables that are going to be used. Using static typing can help with code management (especially in larger projects) as well as it speeds up code execution. More about this mechanism can be read in PEP484 and in the docs here. Mentioning static typing it's worth saying that Python is (and will remain) dynamically typed language and any type hints (with all their usefulness) are not mandatory by convention.
